 <entry>
    <title>Vishal Khetpal:  Was the First GOP Debate Really a Debate?</title>
            <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/vishal-khetpal/was-the-first-gop-debate-_b_7988900.html" />
        <id>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/vishal-khetpal/was-the-first-gop-debate-_b_7988900.html</id>
    
    <published>2015-08-14T12:25:57Z</published>
    <updated>2015-08-14T15:53:42Z</updated>
    
    <author>
        <name>Vishal Khetpal</name>
        <uri>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/vishal-khetpal/</uri>
    </author>
    <content type="html" xml:lang="en-US" xml:base="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/">
		        Let's call the first GOP debate, and the debates to come, what they really are. Last week, in an effort to further conflate entertainment with politics, Fox News packed ten candidates onto a stage to answer a meandering set of questions, designed to fulfill an agenda, and not to start a discussion. Let's not call it a debate.
        	    <p>Read more: <a href="/tag/2016-election">2016 Election</a>, <a href="/tag/donald-trump">Donald Trump</a>, <a href="/tag/ben-carson">Ben Carson</a>, <a href="/tag/fox-news">Fox News</a>, <a href="/tag/presidential-debates">Presidential Debates</a>, <a href="/tag/uk-election">UK Election</a>, <a href="/tag/canada-election-2015">Canada Election 2015</a>,  <a href="/media">Media News</a></p>

	    </content>

    <title>Niall Ferguson:  The Rise and Fall of Krugmania in the UK</title>
            <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/niall-ferguson/the-rise-and-fall-of-krugmania-in-the-uk_b_7257236.html" />
        <id>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/niall-ferguson/the-rise-and-fall-of-krugmania-in-the-uk_b_7257236.html</id>
    
    <published>2015-05-11T12:40:07Z</published>
    <updated>2015-05-11T12:40:48Z</updated>
    
    <author>
        <name>Niall Ferguson</name>
        <uri>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/niall-ferguson/</uri>
    </author>
    <content type="html" xml:lang="en-US" xml:base="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/">
		        It is already conventional to name the former party leaders Ed Miliband, Nick Clegg and Nigel Farage as the biggest losers of the British general election. But this is to understate the abject defeat suffered by some Keynesian economists, and in particular the Nobel prize winning former Princeton professor Paul Krugman.

	    </content>

            </entry> <entry>
    <title>David Coates:  The UK Election: US Lessons</title>
            <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-coates/the-uk-election-us-lesson_b_7253054.html" />
        <id>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-coates/the-uk-election-us-lesson_b_7253054.html</id>
    
    <published>2015-05-10T18:15:04Z</published>
    <updated>2015-05-10T18:15:04Z</updated>
    
    <author>
        <name>David Coates</name>
        <uri>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-coates/</uri>
    </author>
    <content type="html" xml:lang="en-US" xml:base="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/">
		        American observers of UK politics would do well to see the U.S. parallels here. The dilemma facing the UK Labour Party is basically the one faced by Democratic presidential candidates as they seek victory in 2016. If either major UK political party fails to find its way, the US stands poised to lose its most reliable European ally.

	    </content>

            </entry> <entry>
    <title>Arianna Huffington:  Sunday Roundup</title>
            <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/arianna-huffington/sunday-roundup_388_b_7248960.html" />
        <id>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/arianna-huffington/sunday-roundup_388_b_7248960.html</id>
    
    <published>2015-05-10T00:02:10Z</published>
    <updated>2015-05-10T00:01:55Z</updated>
    
    <author>
        <name>Arianna Huffington</name>
        <uri>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/arianna-huffington/</uri>
    </author>
    <content type="html" xml:lang="en-US" xml:base="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/">
		        This week saw the first conservative government reelected to a second term in the U.K. since Margaret Thatcher's. Returns showed David Cameron winning easily, with Labour and the Liberal Democrats losing big. But the other clear losers were the pollsters, along with anyone who believed their predictions of a virtual tie. Pollsters are not exactly on a roll. In March, polls wrongly showed a dead-heat in Israel between the Zionist Union party and Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud, which, in fact, won handily. And here at home, polls in the 2014 midterms overestimated Democrats in Senate races by four percent. As three new candidates -- Mike Huckabee, Carly Fiorina and Ben Carson -- tossed their hats into the crowded presidential ring this week, it's a good time to remind ourselves about the folly of breathless poll-obsessed political coverage. It's the people, not the polls, that matter. And focusing on the horse race at the expense of debating real issues makes losers of us all.
        	    <p>Read more: <a href="/tag/uk-election">UK Election</a>, <a href="/tag/david-cameron">David Cameron</a>, <a href="/tag/israel-likud-party">Israel Likud Party</a>, <a href="/tag/benjamin-netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a>, <a href="/tag/mike-huckabee">Mike Huckabee</a>, <a href="/tag/carly-fiorina">Carly Fiorina</a>, <a href="/tag/ben-carson">Ben Carson</a>,  <a href="/politics">Politics News</a></p>

	    </content>
